noun.description: An enclosed stall in a church divided by a screen or curtain in which a priest sits to hear people confess their sins.
An admission or acknowledgment that one has done something that one is ashamed or embarrassed about; a confession.

adjective.description: (especially of speech or writing) in which a person reveals or admits to private thoughts or past incidents, especially ones that cause shame or embarrassment.
Relating to confessions of faith or doctrinal systems.
examples: the confessional approach to religious education

origin: Late Middle English (as an adjective): the adjective from confession + -al; the noun via French from Italian confessionale, from medieval Latin, neuter of confessionalis, from Latin confessio(n-), from confiteri acknowledge (see confess).
